elements.text: PART ONE
1. TARDIS CONSOLE ROOM
(FX: CONSOLE ROOM HUM. WE JOIN OUR HEROES MID-ARGUMENT. DOCTOR
FIDDLING WITH CONTROLS. JUST LEFT ‘ENLIGHTENMENT’ )
In case you’ve forgotten, Doctor, Turlough was trying to kill us!
I do realise that, Tegan. But you have to understand, when he agreed to act on the Black Guardian’s behalf, he didn’t know what he was getting himself into!
Yeah, right! He agreed to work for a bloke with a dead crow on his head! Nothing suspicious there!
It might also be worth bearing in mind that when he entered into the contract, it was before he’d met any of us.
That’s no excuse! If anything, that’s worse! He was prepared to murder somebody he didn’t even know!
But the point is, he didn’t. He had the opportunity, time and time again, but did nothing. Doesn’t that tell you something?
Yes — it tells me he’s incompetent! The only reason you’re not floating through space with a big hole in your head is because whenever he tried to bump you off, he messed it up!
But in the end he chose not to! Remember, he tried to end his own life, simply to be free of the Black Guardian’s influence.
You’re not the one who spent half a day stuck in a ventilation shaft with him! He creeps me out.
Anybody can make a mistake, Tegan.
FX: INTERIOR DOOR OPENS
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 3
And you made a mistake by letting him onboard! As my Aunt Vanessa used to say: ‘Once a wrong un, always a wrong un’!
Ah, Turlough. Have a good rest?
Doctor. Tegan.
(MUTTERS) No need to look so pleased. There’s nothing I’d say behind your back that I wouldn’t happily repeat to your face!
AWKWARD PAUSE
Turlough. So. You, ah, ready to return to your home planet?
Oh, don’t mind me! You two chat away. All boys together!
FX: INTERIOR DOOR SLAMS
2. SPACECRAFT (FX: INTRODUCTORY SPACESHIP MUSIC AND SWHOOSH...! FLYPAST.
ENGINES RUMBLES. INSTRUMENTS CHIRP AND BLEEP.
NYSSA’S COMPANION IS LOKI (LOW-KEY), A ROBOT. THINK C3PO, BUT WITH THE VOCAL EFFECT USED ON ROBOTS IN ‘TERMINUS’. )
Hyperspace jump completed. This is the place. The planet Helheim.
I don’t like the look of it, Miss Nyssa.
You never like the look of anything, Loki. I’ve never known a robot more easily terrified.
It’s called having a healthy sense of self-preservation.
That would explain the time you corrupted your back-up server at the sight of your own shadow.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 4
It was dark, I was in threat-mode!
I had to wipe your hard drive clean! Initiate remote scan.
FX: SENSORS BLEEP
Toxic atmosphere, predominantly sulphur and carbon oxides. Electrical storms and acid precipitation. Planet’s surface highly unconducive to life. Organic or artificial.
Yes, I take the point, Loki. But we’re not here for fresh air. Energy traces?
Scanning... one non-indigenous power source. Very weak.
That must be it. The research station.
They’re broadcasting a signal, it’s extremely faint...
FX: RADIO ACTIVATED. THROUGH HISSING STATIC WE HEAR EDGAR.
This is Helheim gene-tech facility. We are in a state of
emergency quarantine. Do not attempt to land.
FX: MESSAGE REPEATS AUTOMATICALLY IN THE BACKGROUND
An automatic recording. It must’ve been playing for the last forty years.
FX: RADIO SWITCHED OFF
Is that all you have to say? Didn’t you hear the part about ‘emergency quarantine’?
I’m sure everything will be fine. So long as I have you to look after me.
That’s all very well, but who’s going to look after me?
You can multi-task, can’t you? Commencing descent. Hold tight, Loki. We’re going down...
FX: DURING THIS, CONTROLS ARE ACTIVATED, ENGINES THUNDER
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 5
3. TEGAN’S ROOM/TARDIS CORRIDOR
FX: MUSIC; CLASSICAL, SOOTHING. THERE’S A KNOCK ON THE DOOR
Yes?
FX: MUSIC TURNED DOWN AND OFF. DOOR OPENS
Oh, it’s you.
I’ve come to say goodbye.
Is that so?
The Doctor’s taking me home. We’1ll be landing soon. Then you’ll never have to set eyes on me again.
Thanks for relaying the good news.
Well, that’s all I came to say.
You’re not going to apologise, then? For trying to kill me and the Doctor?
I already have apologised. I’m sorry, Tegan, I’1ll say it again a thousand times if it helps!
You can say it all you like. But do you mean it?
Yes, I do. But I wouldn’t expect you to believe me. So...
FX: DOOR CLOSES. BEAT
(FRUSTRATED) Oh, rabbits.
FX: DOOR OPENS. FOLLOW HER AS WE MOVE INTO CORRIDOR
(CALLS) Turlough! Turlough, wait up!
(STOPPING) Yes?
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 6
(ARRIVING) You don’t have to leave the TARDIS on my account.
I thought, you and the Doctor — you don’t need me around... what’s the Earth expression? A ‘third wheel’? A gooseberry?
No, it’s just with Nyssa going, it’s all been a bit sudden.
You miss her?
I haven’t had time! It would be nice to have a chance to take it all in, let the dust settle.
She seemed nice.
You barely spoke two words to her!
I know, but.. well, I realise I’m not much of a replacement.
So we’re going to see where you come from. What’s it like?
Well, it’s not exactly where I come from.
But it’s where your family are, right?
Not quite.
Turlough, what are you up to?
It’s complicated. The situation with my family, — (I mean)
FX: A GRINDING GROAN AS THE TARDIS LURCHES OUT OF CONTROL
& TURLOUGH (KNOCKED SIDEWAYS) Woah!
What’s happening?
The TARDIS. Something’s wrong!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 7
4. AIRLOCK
(FX: THE CLANGGG! OF AN AIRLOCK DOOR HISSING SHUT... NYSSA AND
APPROACH. NYSSA’S VOICE IS MUFFLED — SPEAKING USING SPACE
RADIO. LOKI WHIRRS AS HE MOVES. ‘ALIENS’ ATMOS)
Loki. Any signs of life?
Nothing, as far as I can detect. The whole base is... cold.
What about the atmosphere? There’s some superficial weather damage, but the airlock itself appears to be intact.
According to my sensors, the base’s integrity has not been compromised. No traces of contamination.
No bacteria, viruses, parasites, prions, fungi or toxins?
None. It’s clean.
Would you stake your life on it?
Well, no, but I’m not [organic] — (REALISING) Miss Nyssa!
FX: BUT IT’S TOO LATE. SHE’S REMOVED HER HELMET
(BREATHES DEEPLY) That’s better. A little dry and dusty perhaps (SHIVERS) — and virtually freezing — but otherwise fine.
You can’t be sure... there might be a non-detectable pathogen!
Still jumping at your own shadow? Come on, Loki. This way.
Speaking of shadows. I’d feel happier if there were some lights on in here.
Just watch where you’re treading.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 8
FX: THEY MOVE INSIDE. FOOTSTEPS ON METAL
How can I watch where I’m treading when you have the torch?
There should be a schematic in the entrance, all these stations have the same layout.
FX: METALLIC BANG FOLLOWING BY ELECTRONIC FIZZING
Ow!
I said to watch out.
You said I should watch where I was treading. You never said anything about minding my head!
Here it is. (READS) Control room, laboratory, crew quarters... Back-up generators!
What’re you’re looking for?
A way to get the lights back on. The generator stacks are four levels down, and the elevator won’t be functioning, so we’1ll have to use the access shaft. Loki? (LOUDER) Loki!
The schematic.. could you shine the light over here again?
What is it?
Six levels down. ‘Unidentified subterranean ruins’.
Interesting. We shall have to take a look.
Must we?
After I’ve got the lights back on. First things first...
FX: THEY WALK FOR A FEW SECONDS, THEN:
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 9
Aaargh!
What is it this time?
I stepped on something, I stepped on something!
Hold still, wait until I can see what I’m doing... don’t worry. It’s just some cobwebs.
Cobwebs?
Yes. There... they’re everywhere. This whole section of the airlock’s outer wall...
You know what cobwebs mean.
What? What do cobwebs mean?
Spiders.
I thought you said there were no life signs... wait. There you are. Your ‘spider’.
FX: A METALLIC RATTLE, LIKE A SMALL TOY BEING SHAKEN
A robot maintenance spider! Oh, thank the goodness of Freya!
It’s deactivated. It must have run out of energy.
FX: SPIDER DISCARDED
Excuse me, that landed on my foot.
FX: CREAKY METAL DOOR OPENED
Here we are. ‘Access shaft’. Are you coming with me — or would you prefer to wait here, alone in the cold and dark?
I think I’1l keep you company...
FX: NYSSA STARTS CLIMBING DOWN CLANGING METAL LADDER...
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 10
5. CONSOLE ROOM
(FX: TURLOUGH AND TEGAN RUNNING IN. TARDIS WHEEZING AND GROANING. SPACE TURBULENCE. DOCTOR PRESSING BUTTONS. )
Doctor! — [What’s —]
[What’s happening? ]
If you’re about to ask what’s happening, the answer is, I don’t know! Some kind of disturbance has dragged the TARDIS off-course.. and is pulling us down in a temporal spiral!
Down? Down to where?
Not sure. It’s as if something is trying to force us to materialize...
Can’t you increase the power so the TARDIS can break free?
That’s what I’m trying to do. Trouble is, it’s rather difficult to increase the power when it’s already on ‘maximum’ !
FX: BUTTONS BEING PUSHED. CONSOLE THUMPED
Do you think it could be a Black Guardian trap?
(SARCASTIC) Yes, Tegan, causing us to crash-land on a distant planet is exactly the sort of thing that might lull us into a false sense of security.
(MUTTERS) Could be a double-bluff.
How long can the TARDIS withstand it?
Not indefinitely. No choice! I’m going to have to perform a materialisation flip-flop. Hold tight!
You know, you really should fit this thing with safety belts!
FX: BY THIS POINT, TARDIS JUDDERING OUT OF CONTROL
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 11
6. SOLAR GENERATORS
FX: ANOTHER DOOR CREAKS OPEN
Hurry up, Loki. You’re supposed to be my guardian...!
I’m doing the best I can. I wasn’t built for vertical descent. And I’ve got cobwebs stuck to my ocular feed.
Here. Is that better?
FX: WIPING METAL
A little. (BEAT) So these are the power generators?
Yes. Hold the torch for me, could you?
FX: BUTTONS PRESSED
Just as I thought!
What is it?
While the main solar stack has been exhausted, the back-up has enough power to keep the lights on for a day or so.
Oh. That’s good news.
All I have to do is switch to secondary input, and...
FX: BUTTONS . POWER. FLUORESCENT LIGHTS FLICKERING ON.
Ah! Can see where we are now.
We should be able to access the neuronic logs as they come back online. Find out precisely what the crew were working on before they died...
You’re sure that’s a good idea?
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 12
We can hardly return [empty-handed] — What was that?
What was what?
I thought I saw something move. Near the access shaft. Scan for life-signs!
Scanning...
(FX: QUIETLY AT FIRST, WE HEAR THE SQUEAL OF THE CRACTIDS. A MIXTURE OF SCUTTLING FEET, SNAPPING CLAWS AND EXCITED HUNGRY
CHITTERS. AS TERRIFYING AS POSSIBLE. )
There... some sort of crustacean, with an exoskeleton, two claws, eight, no, six legs, and mandibles, like a scorpion!
I’m not detecting any signs of life.
But you must... There are two of them... three.. — Loki, neutralise them! (BEAT) You’re meant to protect me!
FX: THE CREATURES SCUTTLE ACROSS THE STEREO IMAGE. CLOSE!
I’m sorry, Miss Nyssa, but according to my sensors there’s nothing there... No heat, no electromagnetic radiation —
You can’t see them?
No.
But they’re on my legs... (OW!) Get them off me! (SCREAMS) Help me! Help!
(FX: THE CRACTIDS ARE EVERYWHERE. THE LISTENER SHOULD FEEL AS
THEIR HEAD IS STUCK IN A BUCKETFUL OF LOBSTERS).
I’m sorry, but I am unable to perceive any threat.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 13
7. CONSOLE ROOM
FX: TARDIS LANDS WITH A BUMP
DOCTOR, TEGAN AND TURLOUGH
LANDING WITH A BUMP
There. That wasn’t so bad, was it?
I feel like my stomach and my heart have swapped places.
Really? Then I’d avoid eating for half an hour. Now let’s see where we are...
FX: TARDIS SCANNER
Oh great, another gloomy corridor.
Where are we?
As far as I can tell, the eastern edge of the galaxy. Far out in the uncharted backwaters.
In a corridor.
Yes. Sterile atmosphere, gravity normal... Let’s take a look outside, shall we?
Are you sure that’s such a clever idea?
Tegan’s right, Doctor. If something brought us here —
- then I would rather like to find out why.
FX: TARDIS DOOR OPENING, CUTTING DIRECTLY TO:
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 14
8. BASE CORRIDOR
FX: TARDIS EXTERIOR DOORS OPENING
Ugh! This place looks like it’s seen better days.
Mmm? Oh, the cobwebs. Yes. Odd that.
Odd?
No smell of decay, no build-up of dust.
So what’s with all the cobwebs then? Cleaners on strike?
FX: ROBOT SCUTTLING SOUND
Whatever you do, Tegan, don’t move. Stay perfectly still, look down slowly and try not to scream.
Scream? You [patronising —] (WINCES) What is it?
FX: METALLIC TOY BEING LIFTED. RATTLING. QUIET BEEPING.
A maintenance spider.
Yes. Rather endearing, isn’t it? It must be responsible for all the cobwebs.
What for? To catch robot flies?
No. Some sort of protective sealant... yes, look. (BLOWS DUST) See where the insulation has burned through? Neat system.
FX: RELEASES REPAIR SPIDER. IT SCUTTLES AWAY, BLEEPING
So the robot coats the damage, before beginning its repairs?
Yes. Even down to a micromolecular level, I should imagine.
Is it dangerous?
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 15
Completely harmless. This one must be running low on juice, to leave a job half-finished. (BEAT) Ah! Crew quarters!
FX: DOOR OPENING.
Hello? Anyone at home?
If there is, they should take a look at their thermostat. (SHIVERS) It’s like walking around in a freezer in here.
Tegan, your capacity to complain never ceases to astound me.
Hey, if you ever landed us somewhere half-way decent you wouldn’t hear a peep out of me.
FX: DOOR OPENED. A DRAWER FORCED OPEN AND RUMMAGED THROUGH
Turlough, has no-one ever told you that’s it’s not polite to rummage around in other people’s property?
First aid equipment, disinfectant, laboratory clothes — it seems somebody left in a hurry!
Yes. If they did leave. Strangely spartan, don’t you think?
Spartan? Oh. No framed photographs. No bedside reading.
Exactly. No personal effects at all. Anonymous.
And there’s no windows either. It must be like living ina submarine.
FX: AS SHE SAYS THIS, DISTANT CLANG
What was that?
Shhh.
FX: ANOTHER DISTANT CLANG
We’re not alone.
No.. — no, it doesn’t sound like we are!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 16
9. SOLAR GENERATORS
FX: LIFT DESCENDING, CLATTER CLATTER, DOORS OPENING
It seemed to come from down here. Come on!
(WHISPERS) What’s this? The engine room?
Yes. Solar stack generators. Primitive, but effective.
(CALLS OUT) Hello! We don’t mean you any harm.
When has saying that ever worked?
You don’t have to hide, you know...
FX: SUDDENLY WHIRRING AS LOKI TRUNDLES IN IN DEFENCE MODE
Warning! Threat-mode activated. You will remain motionless. Any unanticipated movement will be considered an act of aggression.
Good grief, what is it?
It doesn’t appear to be armed.
I am equipped with numerous defence mechanisms. Do not move
any closer. This is your final warning!
Don’t worry, we're not going to [hurt you —] (HURT) Ow!
FX: THE DOCTOR HAS BEEN ZAPPED WITH A BOLT OF ELECTRICITY
There was no call for that.
It’s alright, Loki. I know them. They’re not hostile.
[Standing down as instructed. De-activating threat-mode. ]
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 17
(OVER LOKI’S LINE)
Nyssa!
Doctor! Tegan!
What are you doing here?
I could ask you the same question.
But Nyssa, you... you look [older —]
Older? Well, it has been a while since the last time I saw you.
How long?
About fifty years.
Fifty years? You’re looking pretty good for seventy!
You forget, Tegan, I do not age at the same rate as you.
But even so... sorry, what am I saying? I’m just amazed to see you, I never thought I’d see you again.
I’m glad to see you too. You don’t look very different from how I remember, any of you, not even your clothes. Doctor, how long has it been?
Since we said goodbye on Terminus? Two days.
Two days!
Well, time is, ah, relative.
You can say that again!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 18
Oh, Nyssa. I’m sorry, it’s been such a long time...
There’s no need to apologise. I always knew you would come back one day — but that I shouldn’t hold my breath waiting.
Hello. Don’t know if you remember me. Turlough.
From Brendon School. So you’re travelling with the Doctor now?
It’s a long story. He’s on probation.
So, what have you been up to? Your work with the Lazars?
Ended, almost fifteen years ago. Since I developed a vaccine there hasn’t been a new case for over two decades.
I always knew you would do well.
But what are you doing here? Wherever ‘here’ might be.
A gene-tech station on the planet Helheim. Forty years ago the crew here were engaged in research into Richter’s Syndrome.
Richter’s Syndrome?

We thought it had been wiped out, until ten years ago, when suddenly a new, more powerful strain emerged as though from nowhere. Within months it had spread across the galaxy. We estimate that over six billion people are now infected.
Six billion? That’s more than the population of Earth!
And the crew of this station were studying it, you say?
Our hope is that they discovered a cure. Unless we find some way of stopping it, whole worlds will be wiped out.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 19
And your metal friend?
This is Loki. My companion and protector.
(LAUGHS) He’s your bodyguard?
Amongst other things. He also acts as my personal databank.
Like a walking, talking filofax!
Loki, these are my friends, the Doctor, Nyssa and Turlough. You are to obey their commands as you would mine.
Updating records. Will the Doctor be requiring an apology?
That won’t be necessary. So Nyssa, is that why you summoned us here? To help?
Summoned you here? I don’t know what you’re talking about.
But if you didn’t bring the TARDIS here, then who did? It does seem an awfully big coincidence...
(READS) ‘Unidentified subterranean ruins’.
What?
On the map of the base. It appears to have been constructed on top of some sort of alien remains!
Interesting!
You think there might be something down there? Whatever it was that dragged the TARDIS off course?
Well, it’s got to be worth a look, surely?
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 20
While you’re doing that, Doctor, I’d like to visit the control room, access the neuronic logs. Find out what happened to the crew.
Good idea. Tegan can go with you — give you a chance to catch up on old times!
And what if there’s something in here with us?
Don’t worry, Tegan. With Loki to protect us, we’re perfectly safe.
‘Perfectly safe’? I’ve heard that one before. Usually five seconds before something explodes.
10. CONTROL ROOM
FX: PULLING AT METAL DOOR
‘Research station control room?’ The door’s sealed shut.
Try the entry coder.
(MUTTERS) For all the good it’ll do us. (RESIGNEDLY, AS SHE
BUTTONS) One-two-three-four...
FX: BUTTONS PUSHED. NO EFFECT
Nothing. Loki, can you over-ride the door security mechanism?
Miss Nyssa. I’m not sure that’s a good idea...
Just do as you’re told, please.
FX: MECHANISM ACTIVATED. DOOR GRINDS OPEN. THEY ENTER
I don’t believe it — a superstitious robot!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 21
It’s his job, to be sensitive to potential dangers. Sometimes I think I should put him on a lower setting.
Well, there’s nothing to worry about in here. Just a load of old computers.
(WORRIED) They should be back on-line by now...
FX: CRUNCH OF GLASS
What was that?
Some broken glass on the floor. No, not glass. Crystal.
Maybe they were using this place for a Jewish wedding. Which reminds me, I must have fifty years of gossip to catch up on. So, has there been anyone to help pass you your test-tubes?
(INTERRUPTING) Miss Nyssa! Activating threat-mode. We are not alone.
Loki? What do you mean?
I am detecting a fourth sentient presence.
Where is it? I can’t see anything.
It’s all around us... it’s the station itself!
The base computer!
FX: AND BY WAY OF RESPONSE THE COMPUTER CHIMES INTO LIFE.
I always knew you would return, one day.
Return? What are you on about?
That the four of you would come back to me. Tegan. Nyssa. Turlough. And the Doctor...
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 22
11. SUBTERRANEAN RUINS
FX: DOCTOR AND TURLOUGH SLIPPING ON RUBBLE, ROCKS CLINKING.
Fascinating! These ruins must be over two thousand years old... Ha! Through here — mysterious engravings!
Doctor. Can I ask you a question?
(OBSERVING ALOUD) Some sort of eroded iconography... Go on.
Why do you trust me?
Why? Well, do you trust me?
Yes, of course.
Then it would be ungracious not to return the compliment.
But when did you realise... about the Black Guardian...
(CHANGING THE SUBJECT) You know, there must have been quite an advanced civilisation here once!
With sufficient technology to force the TARDIS to land?
Possibly. It’s times like this I wish I still had my sonic screwdriver. Or a decent pickaxe.
(DISTURBED) Doctor...
(ENGROSSED) Hmmm?
Look! By the lift shaft.
(CURIOUS) I can’t see anything.
(CALLING) No, keep back, please, don’t [shoot —]
FX: GUN FIRES LASER, TURLOUGH COLLAPSES INTO ROCKS
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 23
(STUNNED) Aaaaargh!
Turlough!
12. CONTROL ROOM
Computer. Question. How do you know who we are?
You identified yourselves. When you first came here.
What d’you mean, when we first came here?
You arrived forty years, two months and two days ago.
What? No we didn’t!
Tegan, we must have been here before!
But I’d remember! I never forget a disembodied voice!
But maybe for us it has yet to take place. As the Doctor says — time is relative.
It might be relative to you but it’s extremely confusing to me.
Miss Nyssa, maybe, er, we should relocate to the scout ship?
Not yet. Computer. How did you know we would come back?
You promised Edgar. You promised you would return.
Did we?
Edgar has been so lonely. Please have pity on poor Edgar! Edgar begs you most cravenly. Pity me! Pity me! PITY ME!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 24
13. SUBTERRANEAN RUINS
FX: TURLOUGH WAKING, DOCTOR SHIFTING ROCKS.
(COMING TO) Doctor... What happened?
You collapsed. What’s the last thing you remember?
There was someone here... I couldn’t make out their face... but they had a weapon of some kind, a gun. They fired at me!
I see. Can you stand? (HEAVE)
FX: TURLOUGH BEING HELPED UP
(STARTLED) Where did they go? Doctor, [are they —]
It’s alright. There’s no-one there.
You didn’t see anything?
No. But I think you did. An hallucination, perhaps?
Doctor, it was more than an hallucination. I felt the laser hitting my chest! I could smell it burning my clothes —
And yet you are entirely unmarked. Come on! Time we got back to the others!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 25
14. CONTROL ROOM
If you want us to help you, you have to tell us what you want!
Edgar has been so lonely. So lonely!
If you ask me, it’s gone mad. All these years on its own must have sent it completely around the bend.
It’s possible that some of the neural pathways may have corroded while the computer was in hibernation.
FX: DOOR OPENS
Doctor, Turlough, did you find anything?
The remains of some sort of ancient structure. What about you?
Doctor, the station computer. It claims we have been here before!
Does it now? How very intriguing.
Maintaining threat-mode. I can still hear it... in my mind.
Of course! That must be it!
Must be what?
What happened to Turlough. A telepathic memory projection!
You mean, what I saw was somebody else’s memory?
Precisely! Stored in the computer, then fed back into your consciousness, vividly accurate in every detail.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 26
Doctor. Just before I met you I also had a vision that I was being attacked, by some creatures, like scorpions...
The same process! What you saw was the memory of one of the crew of this base, being played back, like a recording!
But I was looking through the eyes of somebody as they were being murdered! If it was the same for Nyssa —
You were experiencing their moments of death. Yes. Curious!
Curious? Is that all you can say? It’s downright morbid!
FX: DOCTOR ACTIVATING CONTROLS
If these memories in the computer, there should be others...
Doctor. You have returned to me. As you promised you would.
Did I?
You said you would release Edgar, from the endless unrelenting agony of existence...
Cheerful soul, aren’t you? Sorry, who is ‘Edgar’?
It’s what the computer calls itself.
Of course — Encephalic Data Gathering And Research! Tell me, Edgar, do you have any records of the original crew of this base?
Projecting.
(FX: DISORTED, CRACKLY CLIP FROM SCENE 28. VALIS: But nobody outside the Company knows we’re here. IT CONTINUES IN B/G)
A hologram!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 27
Not quite. A shared sensory impression. A group hallucination!
This is the whole crew? Three people?
Edgar. Identify station personnel.
Helheim gene-tech facility. Director Cardell.
(FX: CLIP FROM SCENE 41: I didn’t make the system. I only try to live in it.)
Bio-technician Valis.
(FX CLIP FROM SCENE 36: You’ll have to manage without me. I can’t just drop what I’m doing.)
Enforcement Officer Bragg.
(FX CLIP FROM SCENE 30: Impossible. There’s nowhere within range.)
It’s so real. It’s almost as if we were there with them...
Maybe we were... Edgar — have there been any other visitors to this base?
Projecting.
(FX: CLIP FROM SCENE 57: NYSSA: Doctor! DOCTOR: Nyssa, Turlough, Cardell! No time to explain —)
That’s us! That’s us!
Edgar, end projection.
FX: PROJECTION ENDS
Hey, I was watching that!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 28
Not healthy to know too much about one’s own future.
What you talking about? We don’t know what happened to these people. We don’t know what happened to us!
And we can’t know, don’t you see? We mustn’t risk finding out something that might prejudice our future actions!
Computer! What happened to the crew of this station?
Pity poor Edgar. Pity me! Pity me! Pity me!

TURLOUGH: There was someone here... I couldn’t make out their face... but they had a weapon of some kind, a gun. They fired at me!
DOCTOR: I see. Can you stand? (HEAVE)
TURLOUGH: (STARTLED) Where did they go? Doctor, [are they —]
DOCTOR: It’s alright. There’s no-one there.
TURLOUGH: You didn’t see anything?
DOCTOR: No. But I think you did. An hallucination, perhaps?
TURLOUGH: Doctor, it was more than an hallucination. I felt the laser hitting my chest! I could smell it burning my clothes —
DOCTOR: And yet you are entirely unmarked. Come on! Time we got back to the others!
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 25
DOCTOR WHO: 14. CONTROL ROOM
NYSSA: If you want us to help you, you have to tell us what you want!
EDGAR: Edgar has been so lonely. So lonely!
TEGAN: If you ask me, it’s gone mad. All these years on its own must have sent it completely around the bend.
NYSSA: It’s possible that some of the neural pathways may have corroded while the computer was in hibernation.
TEGAN: Doctor, Turlough, did you find anything?
DOCTOR: The remains of some sort of ancient structure. What about you?
NYSSA: Doctor, the station computer. It claims we have been here before!
DOCTOR: Does it now? How very intriguing.
LOKI: Maintaining threat-mode. I can still hear it... in my mind.
DOCTOR: Of course! That must be it!
TEGAN: Must be what?
DOCTOR: What happened to Turlough. A telepathic memory projection!
TURLOUGH: You mean, what I saw was somebody else’s memory?
DOCTOR: Precisely! Stored in the computer, then fed back into your consciousness, vividly accurate in every detail.
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 26
NYSSA: Doctor. Just before I met you I also had a vision that I was being attacked, by some creatures, like scorpions...
DOCTOR: The same process! What you saw was the memory of one of the crew of this base, being played back, like a recording!
TURLOUGH: But I was looking through the eyes of somebody as they were being murdered! If it was the same for Nyssa —
DOCTOR: You were experiencing their moments of death. Yes. Curious!
TEGAN: Curious? Is that all you can say? It’s downright morbid!
DOCTOR: If these memories in the computer, there should be others...
EDGAR: Doctor. You have returned to me. As you promised you would.
DOCTOR: Did I?
EDGAR: You said you would release Edgar, from the endless unrelenting agony of existence...
DOCTOR: Cheerful soul, aren’t you? Sorry, who is ‘Edgar’?
TEGAN: It’s what the computer calls itself.
DOCTOR: Of course — Encephalic Data Gathering And Research! Tell me, Edgar, do you have any records of the original crew of this base?
EDGAR: Projecting.
EDGAR: (FX: DISORTED, CRACKLY CLIP FROM SCENE 28. VALIS: But nobody outside the Company knows we’re here. IT CONTINUES IN B/G)
TEGAN: A hologram!
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 27
DOCTOR: Not quite. A shared sensory impression. A group hallucination!
TURLOUGH: This is the whole crew? Three people?
NYSSA: Edgar. Identify station personnel.
EDGAR: Helheim gene-tech facility. Director Cardell.
EDGAR: (FX: CLIP FROM SCENE 41: I didn’t make the system. I only try to live in it.)
EDGAR: Bio-technician Valis.
EDGAR: (FX CLIP FROM SCENE 36: You’ll have to manage without me. I can’t just drop what I’m doing.)
EDGAR: Enforcement Officer Bragg.
EDGAR: (FX CLIP FROM SCENE 30: Impossible. There’s nowhere within range.)
TEGAN: It’s so real. It’s almost as if we were there with them...
DOCTOR: Maybe we were... Edgar — have there been any other visitors to this base?
EDGAR: Projecting.
EDGAR: (FX: CLIP FROM SCENE 57: NYSSA: Doctor! DOCTOR: Nyssa, Turlough, Cardell! No time to explain —)
TEGAN: That’s us! That’s us!
DOCTOR: Edgar, end projection.
TEGAN: Hey, I was watching that!
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 28
DOCTOR: Not healthy to know too much about one’s own future.
TEGAN: What you talking about? We don’t know what happened to these people. We don’t know what happened to us!
DOCTOR: And we can’t know, don’t you see? We mustn’t risk finding out something that might prejudice our future actions!
TEGAN: Computer! What happened to the crew of this station?
EDGAR: Pity poor Edgar. Pity me! Pity me! Pity me!
TEGAN: Never mind that. What happened to the people who were here forty years ago? Where are they? What did you do with them?
EDGAR: You promised Edgar, Doctor. Take the past away! Please!
TEGAN: Where are they, you blasted machine!
EDGAR: Medical bay. Second level.
TEGAN: Right. I’m going to take a look!
DOCTOR: Tegan! (BEAT) Sometimes it feels like I spend half my life chasing after that woman...
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 29
DOCTOR WHO: 15. MEDICAL BAY
TEGAN: Alright. Open this thing up!
EDGAR: The medical bay has been sealed. From the inside.
TEGAN: How does that work? Is there another way in?
EDGAR: Negative.
TEGAN: Doctor, this computer thing says the door’s locked.
DOCTOR: Well, perhaps that’s just as well.
NYSSA: Tegan, the Doctor’s right.
TEGAN: Oh no. There must be some way of getting this thing open. (BEAT) You. Tik Tok.
LOKI: Me?
TEGAN: Can you open this door?
LOKI: I can over-ride the security mechanism. But I don’t think it’s a very good idea...
TEGAN: Never mind that, just do it! Nyssa said you should whatever we ask, didn’t she?
NYSSA: Loki, no!
TURLOUGH: It would appear that it’s too late.
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 30
NYSSA: Scan the atmosphere!
LOKI: No detectable airborne pathogens.
TEGAN: There. Even R-2-D-2 thinks it’s safe.
TEGAN: (FX: TEGAN ENTERING THE MEDICAL BAY, FOLLOWED BY OTHERS.
LIGHTS: FLICKERING ON)
TEGAN: (REACTS) Ugh! What happened to this place? It’s all... cobwebs!
NYSSA: Loki. Any signs of life?
LOKI: None that I can detect, Miss Nyssa.
TURLOUGH: That might be the case, but I don’t think we’re entirely alone.
TEGAN: What do you mean?
TURLOUGH: Look. The beds.
DOCTOR: Four bodies.
TEGAN: Wrapped up in cocoons? There doesn’t seem to be anything left of them apart from the bones.
NYSSA: But there were only three people in the crew...
TURLOUGH: This one, it has some clothes, or what remains of them.
TEGAN: And this one. And just look at what it’s wearing!
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 31
DOCTOR: Some sort of suit.. or a school uniform. Like Turlough’s.
TURLOUGH: And this one’s wearing a survival suit. Like Nyssa’s.
NYSSA: This one has the same clothes that Tegan is wearing now...
TEGAN: And this one has what’s left of a cricketing outfit.
TURLOUGH: Then that would seem to confirm it. These skeletons —
TEGAN: They’re us? Doctor? (BEAT) Doctor?
DOCTOR: Yes. It seems it is our destiny to go back in time and become these corpses. They are all that remains... of our future selves!
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 32

elements.text: PART TWO
16: INT. MEDICAL BAY
REPRISE:
Then that would seem to confirm it. These skeletons...
They’re us? Doctor? (BEAT) Doctor?
Yes. It seems it is our destiny to go back in time and become these corpses. They are all that remains... of our future selves!
No. No, I don’t believe it! It’s a set-up! Something brought the TARDIS here, right? Well, whatever it was, it put these... things here too!
And why do you think they would’ve done that, hmmm?
Somebody’s idea of a sick joke? I don’t know! But whatever the reason is, those bodies are not us.
Tegan does have a point, Doctor. We can’t be absolutely certain these skeletons are our future selves.
I suppose it is a possibility... albeit an unlikely one.
We should at least check. Loki. What do you make of them?
FX: LOKI SCANNING
Remains appear consistent with humanoid organisms. As far as I can detect... oh, Varsak’s beard! They‘re you. The four of you!
Well, if you think I’m trusting the word of that jumped-up one-armed bandit, you’re very much mistaken!
Very well. Nyssa, if you could help me take samples... we’ll see what light the base’s laboratory can shed on the matter.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 33
17: INT. LABORATORY
FX: FADE UP. LABORATORY CENTRIFUGE
How much longer’s it going to take?
Patience. Just getting the results of the spectrographic test!
FX: METAL CAGE RATTLE
Turlough, can’t you leave anything alone for five minutes?
These cages. They’re metal, heavy, reinforced metal.
So?
So I think whatever they were experimenting with here, it was somewhat larger — and more savage — than a virus!
FX: TEST RESULTS BEEP
Well, that appears to be conclusive. The cells of the remains match our own, even down to the genetic signature.
And they would’ve been approximately our ages when they died.
(SARCASTIC) Well, that’s very reassuring!
Couldn’t they be clones of some sort? Duplicates?
It’ll be several centuries before that technology exists in this corner of the galaxy, I’m afraid.
Doctor. There is another possibility. They could be alternative versions of us, from another time-stream. Like when we visited Stockbridge?
There’s one simple way to find out! Tegan, take these scissors, make a cut in the lining of Turlough’s jacket!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 34
(SURPRISED) What?
A cut? Where?
Doesn’t matter, anywhere you like, just a snip. Well, go on!
Alright... but I don’t see [what this —]
Excuse me, but why does it have to be my jacket?
FX: SNIP
Now, Nyssa, the jacket you took from the Turlough skeleton. Is
there a cut in the lining?
(AMAZED) Yes, there — in precisely the same place...
Then that proves it.
(DISMISSIVE) That proves it? A lame-brained conjuring trick?

Tegan, how much more evidence do you need? We know we’ve been here before — or that we will have been here before — because the base computer recognised us, because we’ve seen ourselves in the memory records!
Well, in that case, I’m getting out of here.
Tegan —!
You might want to stick around and get killed, but I’d rather not if it’s all the same to you!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 35
18: INT. CORRIDOR
FX: TEGAN RUNS, DOCTOR FOLLOWING
Tegan, wait! (CATCHES UP) Where do you think you’re going?
Where do you think? Back to the TARDIS!
And then what?
Go somewhere else, anywhere else! Forget this whole place ever existed and never come back!
Running away won’t solve anything.
You want to bet? I say we do our best to make sure we don’t end up as a load of skeletons, and the best way of doing that is by going somewhere as far away as possible!
We can’t do that.
Oh, really?
To use knowledge of the future to prevent it from occurring would cause a temporal negation paradox.
Is that the best you can do? This is my life you’re talking about! Turlough’s life, Nyssa’s life, your life. Isn’t that more important to you than having a few points on your time travel licence?
It doesn’t work like that. I only wish it did.
I don’t care! You’re the Time Lord, you sort it out! But I can tell you one thing.. if those corpses are what the future has in store then it’s a future that I’m not gonna allow to happen!
(FX: DURING THE FOLLOWING, WE SHIFT TO EDGAR’S POINT OF VIEW — AS THOUGH EAVESDROPPING ON THE CONVERSATION WITH HIDDEN MICS)
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 36
But we know we end up travelling back in time —
No, we don’t! You can if you like, but you can include me out!
But you promised me, Doctor. You promised poor Edgar. You can’t leave me alone again. You can’t! You can’t!
FX: AND EDGAR’S EAVESDROPPING SHIFTS TO THE LABORATORY...
19. INT. LABORATORY
Threat-mode increasing, Miss Nyssa. I recommend we return to the scout ship and depart immediately.
(FX: WE LEAVE EDGAR’S POV. NYSSA IS PRESSING BUTTONS, TRYING TO GET THE EQUIPMENT TO WORK)
Not until we’ve got what we came for. The answer must lie in the neuronic logs somewhere.
What was it the Doctor said, about us finding out too much about our own futures?
This is too important. If the people here found a cure —
- the details would be recorded in their memories. Ah. Yes.

I’ve seen similar systems elsewhere. At the end of each day you upload your memories into the database, so you can access them for future reference, share them with others, even recall past events without loss of accuracy.
Ingenious. And I suppose it saves having to write things down!
This might be it — Edgar, play Cardell’s final entry.
(FX: BUTTONS PRESSED. A PROJECTION — DIALOGUE FROM SCENE 63: “This is Director Cardell, Helheim gene-tech research station. We have discovered a cure for Richter’s syndrome, and we —“)
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 37
They did it! Edgar, continue playback.
Unable to comply.
What?
File terminated.
Edgar, play all other memory records relating to research into Richter’s Syndrome.
No records available.
That’s computers for you. Unreliable!
Unless... Loki, could you link your neural [functions —] Loki? Oh, where has that robot go to?
It mentioned something about returning to your scout ship?
(LEAVING) Come on. He can’t have got far...
FX: BUTTONS PRESSED. DOOR OPENS AS THEY LEAVE.
20. INT. CORRIDOR
Tegan, aren’t you even a little bit curious to find out what happened here?
Not if it means my own death, no!
(FX: CLANG. METAL DOOR SLAMS. HISSING SOUND — AIRLOCK CLOSING.
SCENE 56)
What the... that door wasn’t there a second ago!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 38
What door?
Can’t you see it? Like some sort of airlock or bulkhead.
Tegan, close your eyes, concentrate...
And there’s a sound, like escaping gas.. (GASPS) Doctor. I can’t.. I can’t breathe. I can’t breathe!
FX: HISSING GETS LOUDER
Tegan, you’re experiencing another memory projection. It’s not
real, it’s an artificially-induced illusion!
Yes.. but you saying that doesn’t actually help very much!
No. Computer — Edgar. Cancel projection! Cancel!
CAN'T BREATHE
Cancelling.
FX: AIRLOCK SOUND ABRUPTLY SILENCED
(DEEP BREATH) Thank goodness for that. I thought I was going to suffocate!
No, vivid as the experience may be, I don’t think the memories can harm you.
So what just happened, that was what Turlough and Nyssa saw? Somebody’s final moments before they died? Being suffocated in an airlock?
Grisly, isn’t it? Edgar seems to have been instructed to play back those specific memories. I wonder why?
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 39
21. SPACECRAFT
FX: AIRLOCK OPENS, ENGINES RUMBLING, BLEEPING INSTRUMENTS
Loki — what are you doing?
Threat-mode now beyond all toleration levels! Miss Nyssa, I can’t bear it any more. We have to leave — and leave now!
But if you can’t identify the nature of the threat —
It’s inside my mind. I can hear it. (BEAT) It is screaming.
What is? The base computer? Edgar?
It will kill all of you, I know it! I don’t know how, but I can sense what’s going to happen! I can see it!
Those skeletons must have scared him out of his wits.
Loki, I know you’re frightened, but you have to learn to moderate your threat responses.
Please. We have to take off. If we stay here... we’1ll die! I know it!
FX: SCUTTLING REPAIR SPIDER
Nyssa. I don’t want to alarm you, but there’s something in the ship with us — it’s forced open one of the overhead panels —
Maintenance spiders! They must have got in through the fuel ducts.
They were here when I arrived, I couldn’t stop them.
FX: MORE SPIDERS SCUTTLING, BEEPING ABOUT. CIRCUITS FUSING
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 40
They seem more intent on ripping the power feeds to shreds than performing ‘maintenance’.
FX: OMINOUS RUMBLING GROWING LOUDER
According to my sensors, hyperspace drives have begun ignition.
What? But if they’re triggered while the ship’s on the ground
- it will cause a very large explosion.
We have to move. Quick, Loki! Into the airlock!
FX: THEY DASH INTO THE AIRLOCK.
Can’t your metal friend move any faster? He’ll get us killed!
FX: DURING THE FOLLOWING, WE SHIFT TO EDGAR’S POINT OF VIEW
Quickly, Loki, seal the airlock door. Hurry!
FX: WE OVERHEAR EDGAR TALKING TO HIMSELF
Now you can’t leave me. Edgar will never be left alone again!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 41
22. CORRIDOR NEAR AIRLOCK
Alright?
(RECOVERING) It might have only been an hallucination, but it was a bit too realistic for comfort!
Yes. It [would seem —]
FX: MASSIVE EXPLOSION
What was that?
FX: THEY RUN TO WINDOW
Nyssa’s ship. It’s been destroyed!
What? But how —
FX: NYSSA AND TURLOUGH RUN IN, LOKI WHIRRING AFTER.
Nyssa, Turlough, you’re safe. What happened?
My ship... the repair spiders broke in, started dismantling it!
It was deliberate sabotage, Doctor. They caused the explosion.
Or whatever controls them did.
Edgar. Yes. He does seem determined that we shouldn’t leave.
Well, if it wants us to stay, why is it trying to kill us?
FX: EDGAR INTERRUPTS VIA INTERCOM
Edgar does not wish you any harm. Edgar intends to save you!
Save us?
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 42
You have seen your fate. With poor Edgar left in the darkness. Pity me. Pity me!
Yes, you have my sympathy, but how are you trying to save us?
Take the past away. Edgar knows the four of you can travel in time. Edgar, he saw you before, many years ago. The blue box.
It knows about the TARDIS?
I beg you. Please. Go back. Save them. Save poor Edgar!
Of course. It wants us to change the past. Edgar wants us to prevent the base’s crew from being killed!
23. CORRIDOR
FX: ELEVATOR RISING
But if the crew were killed, where are the bodies? Shouldn’t there be three more corpses lying about the place?
Yes. That does seem odd, now you mention it.
I’1l tell you something else that’s odd. If those remains are our future selves — and I’m not admitting they are — but if they are, then where’s their TARDIS?
FX: ELEVATOR STOPS. THEY LEAVE
There’s also the small matter of the alien ruins. If they disturbed something down there, something buried...
Yes. Too many questions. And unfortunately only one way of finding the answers.
By travelling back in the TARDIS.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 43
Oh no. No way. I’d rather live out my days in ignorance.
For what it’s worth, I agree with Tegan. I have no desire to end up a rotting corpse in a research station medical bay!
Nor do I. But with time travel, there are rules. Rules that cannot be broken.
Since when did you ever care for rules?
This is different.
Too right it is!
But Tegan, we don’t have any choice. [We have to —]
Oh, surprise surprise! You’re on the Doctor’s side. As usual!
FX: THEY ARE INTERRUPTED BY EDGAR
Commencing gene-tech facility emergency quarantine procedure.
FX: WARNING ALARM SOUNDS — PRESENT IN BACKGROUND FROM NOW ON
Edgar, what do you mean, emergency quarantine procedure?
Initiating total eradication of Helheim gene-tech facility.
It’s started the self-destruct! If you ask me, that computer’s totally doolally.
No-one is asking you. Edgar, cancel emergency quarantine!
Procedure irreversible. Commencing ignition of plasma fission reactors.
The ultimate safeguard — taking the nuclear option!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 44
(REMEMBERING) Loki. Where is Loki? We have to find him!
Haven’t you got more important things to worry about than that dratted robot?
Tegan, Turlough, go back to the TARDIS, wait for us there.
What about you?
We'll be right behind you. Tegan, you can argue with me later. Run!
At least we’ll be getting out of here!
FX: TEGAN AND TURLOUGH RUN
Doctor, we [need to —]
I know. Edgar, locate Nyssa’s companion, designation — Loki!
Device located in facility control room.
Come on!
FX: THEY RUN
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 45
24. CONTROL ROOM
FX: ALARM LOUDER HERE. DOOR OPENS.
Now, if I can re-initialise the computer’s command protocols —
FX: DOCTOR PUSHING BUTTONS, OPENING UNITS, REWIRING CIRCUITS
Loki! What are you doing here?
Identifying the source of threat-mode. As instructed.
Never mind that. We have to leave, in the Doctor’s TARDIS.
TARDIS? What’s a TARDIS?
It’s a type of time machine, a blue box.
Time machine. Blue box. Updating records.
Doctor?
Nearly there. Just have to by-pass Edgar’s logic functions...
No, Doctor. Pity me. Pity poor Edgar. Permit me to die.
The computer — it’s attempting to commit suicide?
I’m afraid so. Edgar, don’t do this! I’m trying to help you...
Deleting mainframe memory records. Uninstalling all programmes.
Can’t you stop it?
I’m doing my best, but it’s not responding. (THUMPS DESK)
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 46
Memory records twenty per-cent remaining. Fifteen per-cent.
Edgar, listen to me! You’re wiping your own mind!
Pity me. Pity me. Pity me.
FX: EDGAR’S ‘PITY ME’S LOOP AND SPEED UP, THEN SLOW DOWN
It’s dying.
Memory records five per-cent remaining. Four. Three. Two. Logic functions deleted. Primary operating system deleted.
FX: EDGAR’S VOICE SLOWS DOWN, DROPS IN PITCH, HALTS
It’s too late. It’s stopped.
But the countdown to the emergency quarantine hasn't!
No. You’re right. There’s nothing we can do. We have to go!
FX: THEY LEAVE
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 47
25. CONSOLE ROOM
FX: DOORS OPEN. DOCTOR AND NYSSA DASH IN
Doctor, what happened?
I’ll explain later. Close the doors, we've only a few seconds left!
Wait, Loki’s still outside. (CALLS TO HIM) Hurry, Loki!
FX: LOKI WHIRRS IN
I’m sorry, Miss Nyssa. I wasn’t built for rapid movement.
FX: TARDIS DOORS SHUT. TAKE-OFF BEGINS
Hold on, I’m going to have to perform a temporal shift before
we’re caught in the explosion!
Can’t we just dematerialise?
No time — watch out, here it comes!
FX: MASSIVE EXPLOSION OUTSIDE. TARDIS SHUDDERS VIOLENTLY
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 48
26. CONTROL ROOM
FX: FADE UP. COMPUTER AT WORK. EDGAR NOW YOUNG, SANE VERSION
Edgar. Save my memories, tag Richter’s, research, Director Cardell, day ninety-seven, duration sixteen hours.
Uploading memory record... Memory uploaded.
Marvellous. Have the others saved any new memories yet?
Enforcement Officer Bragg has uploaded one new memory. Tag subterranean ruins research analysis. Duration three hours.
Okay, I think I can cope without having three hours of paranoid speculation downloaded into my brain. Anything else?
FX: ALARM SOUNDS
Alert! Security breach in level three.
What? Visual.
FX: HOLOGRAPHIC PROJECTION. TARDIS LANDING SOUND
What is it, some sort of transmat capsule? Looks archaic.
Object defies analysis. Scanners unable to penetrate exterior. Appearance does not correspond with any known device.
Oh, ice in Hell. The last thing we need. Edgar, get me Valis.
FX: COMMUNICATOR CHANNEL OPENS.
(VIA RADIO) What is it? I’m right in the middle of —
Sorry to interrupt, but, well, you’ve got to see this. A blue
box has just appeared out of nowhere.
FX: WE SHIFT TO THE LAB. CRACTIDS ARE CHITTERING IN THE B/G
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 49
Isn’t this Bragg’s responsibility? I’m really busy right now —
(VIA RADIO)
You’re always busy. Get yourself down there. That’s an order.
FX: WE MOVE BACK TO CONTROL ROOM
(VIA RADIO)
Fine, fine, whatever, I’m on my way.
Edgar, get me Bragg. Don’t tell me, he’s digging up ‘relics’...
FX: ANOTHER COMMUNICATION CHANNEL OPENS
(VIA RADIO)
What do you want, director?
A security breach, level three. Some sort of transmat capsule.
(VIA RADIO)
But that’s impossible, we’re out of range for any — (transmat)
So maybe you should stop skulking around in the dark and do what you’re paid for. Oh, and just in case — armed response.
(VIA RADIO)
Understood. Can’t be too careful!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 50
27. CONSOLE ROOM
FX: SCANNER OPENS
Same location, forty years, two months and two days earlier.
Doesn’t look very different.
What were you expecting?
I don’t know... Except there’s no cobwebs. It’s clean. New.
At this point in time, it is new. The station has only been operational for a few months.
And it seems our presence has not gone entirely unnoticed...
What? Oh, yes. Don’t look very pleased to see us, do they?
CUT TO:
28. BASE CORRIDOR
FX: BRAGG RUNNING A SCAN. MACHINE WHOOPS
What do you make of it? Bragg?
A container of some sort? Made of processed xylem. There’s a door. ‘Pull to open’.
FX: RATTLES DOOR TO NO AVAIL.
You think there’s somebody inside?
Possibly. Could be agents working for one of the independents.
But nobody outside the Company knows we’re here.
Then maybe somebody on the inside tipped them off? What, do you think this thing just landed here by accident?
CUT TO:
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 51
29. CONSOLE ROOM.
So that’s the crew of this place. While they were still alive.
Tegan. If you’re suggesting what I think you’re suggesting —
Why not? We can warn them. Stop them getting killed.
No. What’s done is done.
You’d rather just let them die? That’s what you want?

No! What do you take me for? Don’t you think I’d love to be able to change history? Save Joan of Arc from execution. Prevent Franz Ferdinand being assassinated? Don’t you think I’d do that if I could?
Then why don’t you?
Because I can’t. Because... because —
Because it’s against the rules. The Time Lord code. You said.
Tegan, [if you think —]
Nyssa, don’t say anything! There’s nothing you could say that
would make me less furious right now! I know what you’re going to say; the Doctor’s right, he knows best. Well, in this case, he doesn’t!
I can’t force you to come with me, any of you. You can stay in the TARDIS if that’s what you want.
Too right I’m staying!
Turlough?
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 52
I’m sorry, but I’m with Tegan on this.
Nyssa?
Those people have discovered a cure for Richter’s, that’s all that matters. My personal fate is irrelevant in comparison.
(HUMPH!) I knew it!
Very well. Nyssa — will your, ah, robot friend be joining us?
Loki? You’re very quiet. Are you alright?
All systems at optimum efficiency. I must accompany you. I... I have a duty to make sure you’re safe.
Good. We might need some protection...
FX: DOOR OPENING, TAKING US TO:
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 53
30. BASE CORRIDOR
FX. TARDIS DOOR OPENING, DOCTOR AND NYSSA EMERGE. GUN CLICKS
Don’t move. Either of you.
Hello. I’m the Doctor, this is my friend Nyssa, and her friend, Loki. Don’t worry, we don’t pose any sort of threat!
I said don’t move!

CARDELL: So maybe you should stop skulking around in the dark and do what you’re paid for. Oh, and just in case — armed response.
BRAGG: (VIA RADIO)
BRAGG: Understood. Can’t be too careful!
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 50
DOCTOR WHO: 27. CONSOLE ROOM
DOCTOR: Same location, forty years, two months and two days earlier.
TEGAN: Doesn’t look very different.
DOCTOR: What were you expecting?
TEGAN: I don’t know... Except there’s no cobwebs. It’s clean. New.
NYSSA: At this point in time, it is new. The station has only been operational for a few months.
TURLOUGH: And it seems our presence has not gone entirely unnoticed...
DOCTOR: What? Oh, yes. Don’t look very pleased to see us, do they?
DOCTOR: 28. BASE CORRIDOR
CARDELL: What do you make of it? Bragg?
BRAGG: A container of some sort? Made of processed xylem. There’s a door. ‘Pull to open’.
VALIS: You think there’s somebody inside?
CARDELL: Possibly. Could be agents working for one of the independents.
VANCE: But nobody outside the Company knows we’re here.
CARDELL: Then maybe somebody on the inside tipped them off? What, do you think this thing just landed here by accident?
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 51
DOCTOR WHO: 29. CONSOLE ROOM.
TEGAN: So that’s the crew of this place. While they were still alive.
DOCTOR: Tegan. If you’re suggesting what I think you’re suggesting —
TEGAN: Why not? We can warn them. Stop them getting killed.
DOCTOR: No. What’s done is done.
TEGAN: You’d rather just let them die? That’s what you want?
DOCTOR: No! What do you take me for? Don’t you think I’d love to be able to change history? Save Joan of Arc from execution. Prevent Franz Ferdinand being assassinated? Don’t you think I’d do that if I could?
TEGAN: Then why don’t you?
DOCTOR: Because I can’t. Because... because —
TEGAN: Because it’s against the rules. The Time Lord code. You said.
NYSSA: Tegan, [if you think —]
TEGAN: Nyssa, don’t say anything! There’s nothing you could say that
TEGAN: would make me less furious right now! I know what you’re going to say; the Doctor’s right, he knows best. Well, in this case, he doesn’t!
DOCTOR: I can’t force you to come with me, any of you. You can stay in the TARDIS if that’s what you want.
TEGAN: Too right I’m staying!
DOCTOR: Turlough?
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 52
TURLOUGH: I’m sorry, but I’m with Tegan on this.
DOCTOR: Nyssa?
NYSSA: Those people have discovered a cure for Richter’s, that’s all that matters. My personal fate is irrelevant in comparison.
TEGAN: (HUMPH!) I knew it!
DOCTOR: Very well. Nyssa — will your, ah, robot friend be joining us?
NYSSA: Loki? You’re very quiet. Are you alright?
LOKI: All systems at optimum efficiency. I must accompany you. I... I have a duty to make sure you’re safe.
NYSSA: Good. We might need some protection...
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 53
DOCTOR WHO: 30. BASE CORRIDOR
BRAGG: Don’t move. Either of you.
DOCTOR: Hello. I’m the Doctor, this is my friend Nyssa, and her friend, Loki. Don’t worry, we don’t pose any sort of threat!
BRAGG: I said don’t move!
DOCTOR: As you can see, we’re unarmed. Entirely at your mercy! So there’s absolutely no need to point a gun at us.
CARDELL: What are you doing here? This is a top-security facility!
VALIS: This ‘Police Box’ — it’s your transmat?
DOCTOR: Something like that, yes.
BRAGG: Impossible. There’s nowhere within range. Nowhere!
NYSSA: Our survey ship crashed on the opposite side of the planet. This is our escape capsule.
VALIS: Interesting design.
DOCTOR: Disguise. Based on an old Arcadian prayer booth. Devoted to the great god Pol-ick-eh Box.
BRAGG: Any more of you in there?
DOCTOR: Hardly. Does it look like there’d be room?
CARDELL: You haven’t answered my question. What are you doing here? This system isn’t on any trade routes —
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 54
NYSSA: We’ve come to see you, Director Cardell. Bio-technician Valis.
VALIS: You know who we are?
DOCTOR: Ah, yes. We’re here on behalf of your employers. Inspection!
VALIS: You're from the Company?
DOCTOR: That’s right. Unfortunately our papers were on our ship... but, well, we'd hardly know about this place and who you are, if we weren’t. It is a top secret facility, after all!
NYSSA: We’re here to report on your progress on Richter’s Syndrome.
CARDELL: (LAUGHS) Our progress?
NYSSA: It is the objective of your research?
CARDELL: It’s our objective, but if you’re expecting good news, you’re in for a disappointment.
VALIS: We’ve been working on it for over ninety days without success. We’re still months, if not years, away from finding a cure!
NYSSA: What?
CARDELL: Valis. I think perhaps we should show them our ‘research’...
BRAGG: But we can’t be sure they’re not spies.
CARDELL: Don’t worry, Bragg. If it turns out they’ve been lying to us, I’1ll be only too delighted to let you execute them. But until that time.. Doctor, Nyssa, if you would care to follow me?
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 55
DOCTOR WHO: 31. CONSOLE ROOM.
TURLOUGH: The Doctor seems to have won them over.
TEGAN: It’s a knack he has.
TURLOUGH: I wonder where they’re taking him.
TEGAN: Does it matter? We know where he ends up.
TURLOUGH: Yes. And us too.
TEGAN: Not if we remain in here. We’re safe.
TURLOUGH: How can we be sure of that? For all we know, this might be what we are supposed to do!
TEGAN: What do you mean?
TURLOUGH: I mean, remaining in the TARDIS might be precisely what causes us to end up dead.
TEGAN: Then what do you suggest?
TURLOUGH: You said it yourself. We use our knowledge of the future to prevent it from coming about!
TEGAN: You mean, warn the crew?
TURLOUGH: We know the manner of their deaths. If we can change that then we can save ourselves. Well? Or would you rather stay here and do nothing? Just as the Doctor wanted?
TEGAN: When you put it like that...
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 56
DOCTOR WHO: 32. LABORATORY
NYSSA: (WHISPER) Doctor. Those things, they’re what attacked me in the memory projection! I mean, the person whose memory I saw!
DOCTOR: (QUIET) Probably best to keep that to ourselves for now. (LOUD) Director Cardell, what are these creatures? Some sort of marine crustacean?
CARDELL: Cractids. They’re the reason we’ve come here, aside from the isolation. They’re the only indigenous species on this rock.
NYSSA: They’ve evolved to survive in the toxic atmosphere?
VALIS: More than that. They’re the only organism in the galaxy with a natural immunity to the Richter’s virus.
DOCTOR: So that’s why you’re so interested in them. (SNAPPED) Ouch!
CARDELL: Mind your fingers. A swarm of these things could consume you, flesh and bones, in under a minute.
NYSSA: So you infect them with the virus, then attempt to replicate the antivirals?
CARDELL: Sadly the problem of genetic incompatibility has proved insurmountable. The Cractid response is unique, we can’t splice its genetic pattern into the human immune system.
NYSSA: Have you tried reversing the process?
VALIS: What do you mean?
DOCTOR: (TRYING TO SHUSH HER) Nyssa — !
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 57
NYSSA: Rather than alter the human immune system to mimic the Cractid response, why not adapt the Cractid antigen to function as part of the human immune system?
CARDELL: Because that... actually, that’s not a bad idea.
VALIS: It might just work. It’s got to be worth a try at least...
VALIS: 33. CONTROL ROOM
BRAGG: Edgar, open an emergency com-link with Command Echelon.
EDGAR: Establishing communication. Established. Encryption on.
BRAGG: This is Helheim gene-tech station, Enforcement Officer Bragg speaking.
ECHELON: (VIA RADIO)
ECHELON: Receiving you. What’s the fire? You’re not due to call-in for another orbit cycle.
BRAGG: Report three new arrivals — two humans, one guardian robot. They claim to have been sent by the Company.
ECHELON: (VIA RADIO)
ECHELON: There’s nothing down on the schedule.
BRAGG: Knew it. They’re from an independent.
ECHELON: (VIA RADIO)
ECHELON: You know what to do?
BRAGG: Oh yes. I know what to do. (SIGNING OFF) Praise to Magni and Modi.
ECHELEN: (VIA RADIO) Magni and Modi.
BRAGG: Edgar, shut down com-link.
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 58
EDGAR: Ending communication. Alert. Two more unauthorised personnel have emerged from the object on level three.
BRAGG: What? Visual.
TEGAN: (VIA SCANNER)
TEGAN: Who are we looking for?
TURLOUGH: (VIA SCANNER)
TURLOUGH: We need to speak to someone away from the Doctor and Nyssa, convince them to listen to us, before it’s too late.
BRAGG: Two more spies!
BRAGG: What — oh, the girl’s pet robot. What are you doing here?
LOKI: I.. I don’t know. Investigating source of threat. You must not harm Nyssa and her companions. I must protect them... I... I...
BRAGG: Oh, you’re going to have to try harder than that, my friend.
LOKI: Do not attempt to attack. I am equipped with numerous defence mechanisms!
BRAGG: I don’t take orders from saboteurs.
BRAGG: Well, come on then, shoot back! What’s stopping you?
LOKI: Defensive capability compromised.
BRAGG: Come on! Shoot me, you pathetic machine!
LOKI: Complete systems failure. I... I.. I knew something bad was going to happen! (DIES)
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 59
DOCTOR WHO: 34. LABORATORY
NYSSA: You’re not harming them?
CARDELL: To be honest, they’re so vicious anyway, how would you tell?
NYSSA: So, Valis.. what did you do, before you came here?
VALIS: (SMALL LAUGH) Can’t remember.
NYSSA: You can’t remember?
VALIS: All the crew, when we were assigned to this mission, had our memories erased.
DOCTOR: Interesting. So as far as you’re concerned, you have no past?
VALIS: No past, no family, no friends. The idea is that it frees up brain capacity, makes it simpler for us to pool our memories.
NYSSA: You sound like you don’t mind?
VALIS: How can you miss what you don’t remember? Besides, all our memories are stored on a crystal lattice. When we find the cure, finish our task, then we get our pasts back.
DOCTOR: But until then, you don’t even know who you are. A blank page!
VALIS: Why are you asking all this? It’s standard Company policy.
DOCTOR: Of course. Must have, er, slipped my mind! You know how it is!
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 60
DOCTOR WHO: 35. BASE CORRIDOR
TEGAN: Remind me again why we decided to do this.
TURLOUGH: You can go back to the TARDIS if you like.
BRAGG: No. I wouldn’t attempt to escape, if you want to live.
TURLOUGH: We've been looking for you. We have important information to tell you, about your future!
TURLOUGH: 36. LABORATORY
TURLOUGH: (FX: FUTURISTIC INJECTION MACHINE — THE SAME ONE WE’LL HEAR
BEING: USED IN PART FOUR TO DISPENSE THE ANTIVIRUS CURE.)
VALIS: Injecting modified Cractid antigen into human cell culture...
TEGAN: Hey, watch that thing!
DOCTOR: Tegan. Turlough. I thought you were going to wait in the TARDIS?
TURLOUGH: We, ah, changed our minds.
TEGAN: We have to warn these people, Doctor. Tell them what’s going to happen.
DOCTOR: What? No. Remember what I told you, we mustn’t interfere!
CARDELL: Bragg, who are these people?
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 61
BRAGG: I’ve spoken to Command Echelon. They haven’t sent anyone to check up on us. These people are saboteurs. Spies!
NYSSA: But we’ve been helping you! We’d hardly do that — (if we)
BRAGG: Silence! Valis, Cardell, you know the procedure for dealing with intruders.
VALIS: You’1l have to manage without me. I can’t just drop what I’m doing, the experiment is at a crucial stage...
CARDELL: It’s alright, Bragg, I’1ll assist you.
BRAGG: Then if you’d like to help me escort them to the medical bay...
BRAGG: 37. MEDICAL BAY
BRAGG: Inside!
TEGAN: What are you going to do with us?
BRAGG: You'll see. Each of you. Onto the beds.
TURLOUGH: What?
BRAGG: You heard me. Onto the beds, you — over there — you, ‘Doctor’ — take this one. You, Turlough. And don’t bother struggling, the straps tighten automatically.
DOCTOR: You’re making a terrible mistake!
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 62
BRAGG: How can I be making a mistake? I’m merely following procedure. Director Cardell. Ready with the lethal injections?
CARDELL: Ready.
BRAGG: You should be grateful. It’s a painless death. Instantaneous. One small jab with a needle.. and you’1ll never feel anything ever again.
TURLOUGH: You can’t do this. We’re the only ones who can help you!
TEGAN: We've seen the future. If you kill us, you’re all going to die.
BRAGG: No. I think you’ll find you’re the ones who are going to die.
BRAGG: Director Cardell. If you’d care to commence the injections?
TEGAN: (STRUGGLING) No. No!
CARDELL: Hold still... don’t worry, this won’t hurt a bit...
NYSSA: (WHISPER) Doctor. The four skeletons in the medical bay...
DOCTOR: Yes. It seems our future has finally caught up with us!
DOCTOR WHO: COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 63

elements.text: PART THREE
38. MEDICAL BAY
FX: REPRISE
Director Cardell. If you’d care to commence the injections?
(STRUGGLING) No. No!
Hold still.. don’t worry, this won’t hurt a bit...
Doctor. The four skeletons in the medical bay...
Yes. It seems our future has finally caught up with us!
FX: INTERCOM SOUNDS
(VIA INTERCOM) Director. Stop! Don’t kill them!
What?
Thank goodness! One of you’s seen sense!
Valis, what possible — (reason)
(VIA INTERCOM)
I’ve done it! The modified antivirals have neutralized the virus culture! It works! We’ve found a cure for Richter’s!
That hardly justifies interrupting an execution.
(VIA INTERCOM) Think about it, Bragg. We need test subjects.
(QUIETLY) Oh, rabbits!
Test subjects?
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 64
(VIA INTERCOM)
To check whether the cure is effective on humans. And if not, well, they are expendable...
Expendable!
You don’t have to do this!
Quiet! Valis. You take full responsibility?
(VIA INTERCOM)
Of course. I’1ll start with the woman called Nyssa.
FX: INTERCOM ENDS. STRAPS BEING UNDONE
I’ll bring her. (INSTRUCTION) You. Up.
But my friends, [they —]
Don’t worry, they’1ll get their turn. Now move.
FX: BUTTONS PRESSED. DOOR OPENS, CLOSES
Now if you’d actually pay attention to what we’ve been saying!
You’re in terrible danger, all of you! Everyone in this station is going to end up dead!
Are you threatening me?
It’s not a threat, you big idiot. It’s a warning!

If I were in your shoes, I’d be more concerned about what’s going to happen to you. Once Richter’s takes hold, every nerve cell in your body will be screaming out in agony. It’s not unusual for victims to beg for death. Very soon you’1ll wish you’d been given the lethal injection instead!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 65
39. CORRIDOR
FX: NYSSA BEING DRAGGED ALONG
You don’t have to test the antivirals on any of us! Interpreted correctly, the results [of the cell culture —]
FX: NYSSA BUNDLED INTO A LIFT
Save your strength for the experiment. You’1ll need it.
Director Cardell to proceed to — to facility control room.
FX: THERE IS A GLITCH IN EDGAR’S SPEECH. SUBTLE, BUT THERE
Edgar, I’m in the middle of something, can’t it wait?
Priority one.
Fine, fine. Well, girl, it seems you’ve been granted a second
reprieve — temporarily.
FX: LIFT ASCENDS
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 66
40. MEDICAL BAY
FX: TURLOUGH BEING ROUGHED UP
I said, who are you working for?
And I told you, I don’t work for anyone. We’re from the future!
We’ve seen how each of you will die! In the memory records!
Tegan, what did I tell you about not interfering?
Excuse me, we’re about to be injected with goodness knows what, you think we should just lie back and wait?
I think you will only make matters worse!
I’d like to know how things could be much worse!
Doctor, I think the argument is rather academic. It seems the future has a habit of happening whether we like it or not.
If you were really from the future, then you would know about the ancient ruins. You would know about the secret.
You’ve discovered something?
Oh yes. Something incredible.
Show us.
What?
Show us. Why not? After all, we are at your mercy.
It’s a trick. You don’t believe me, just like the others.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 67
Might I suggest, as a means of guaranteeing our co-operation, you keep our companion here?
Turlough!
Alright. But if you try anything, any treachery — she dies.
FX: STRAPS RELEASED
Why do I always have to be the one who gets tied up and left behind?
Yes.. The woman can come with us. You — Turlough! You can be
the ‘guarantee’!
What? But it was my idea!
FX: STRAPS RELEASED
Brave heart, Turlough! Brave heart!
41. CONTROL ROOM
Okay, Edgar, what is it?
Objective of gene-tech facility has been accomplished. You may now access your memory lattice.
FX: MEMORY LATTICE RELEASED WITH ELECTRONIC HUM
It’s giving you your memories back?
Looks like it. Edgar. Restore!
Restoring.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 68
(FX: RESTORING MEMORIES. SOUND LIKE SPOOLING TAPE. WE HEAR A WAR, LONG AGO, WEAPONS FIRING, EXPLOSIONS, A CHILD'S SCREAMS )
Yes.. I remember. I... my mother. She... the sky filled with fire. I was crying. My children... (GASPS, SHOCK)
FX: WHILE CARDELL RECOVERS, LOKI GROANS
Loki! What’s happened to you?
Systems severely compromised. Unable to engage motor functions. Defensive capability... non-existent!
It’s alright, Loki. I’1ll repair you, — (somehow)
As far as I can tell, I am beyond restoration, I’m afraid, lI...
What?
I am afraid. I am close to the point of inoperability.
Listen, Loki, you reserve your power, the — (Doctor and I)
Director. There is a message included in your memory lattice.
A message? Who from?
Message Signatory: Director Cardell.
Play.
FX: MESSAGE PLAYS. IT’S CARDELL, VOICE SLIGHTLY DISTORTED
(RECORDING)

If you’re hearing this, you’ve found a cure. Congratulations. As your memories are restored, you’ll recall the real purpose of your mission. Your objective is to genetically re-engineer a new, more powerful strain of the Richter’s virus. One which can only be cured using a product licensed to the Company!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 69
FX: MESSAGE ENDS
You don’t look pleased.
What in the name of the nine worlds do you think? (REGAINS COMPOSURE) But it’s who I am.
So your mission wasn’t to find a cure for the disease. You’re here to create a new and more deadly form!

Standard marketing practice. Create a product, then create demand! Once you’ve patented the cure, you re-engineer the virus to be impervious to all other treatments, then release it into society and clean up.
But that’s obscene!
That’s not my concern. The Company’s done it before. Plague as an economic filter! The rich pay for treatment, and any surplus population is... economized.
Billions of innocent people will die!
I didn’t make the system. I only try to live in it.
You still have a choice!

Oh no. I don’t have any choice in the matter. I remember that quite clearly; the lives of my children are dependent upon it. No, a new form of the virus must be generated. (BEAT) And the ironic thing is we couldn’t have done it without you!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 70
42. MEDICAL BAY
FX: TURLOUGH STRUGGLING AGAINST BONDS
(CALLS OUT) Computer. Computer. (BEAT) Edgar!
You wish to communicate?
Listen! My friends and I are from the future. We have travelled back in time, because your future self wanted us to prevent the others from being killed.
I am aware of the explanation for your presence.
Well, then, release me. Use the maintenance spiders! Send them in through the ventilation ducts!
Unable to comply.
What?
You do not have access privileges. I am not authorised to act upon your instructions.
(GIVING UP) Computers!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 71
43. SUBTERRANEAN RUINS
FX: CRAWLING THROUGH RUINS, ROCKS CRUMBLING
What are we looking for? Looks like a load of old rubble to me.
Shhh, Tegan. Mr Bragg has something he wishes to share with us.
FX: THEY HALT
There! Look, can’t you see?
(PLAYING ALONG) Oh, yes. Yes, of course!
I can’t see anything.
Humour him, Tegan. You never know, he might be onto something.
(QUIET) Might be on something, more like!
The inscription. It’s the giveaway!
The giveaway?
What’s down here — it’s our real past. We think we’ve come from the stars, but the truth is, there is nowhere else. This is all there ever has been, ever will be!
(QUIET) He’s round the bend.
Quite possibly. He’s had all memories of the time before he came here removed, bound to play havoc with one’s sanity.
But that’s just it. There was no before. It’s alla lie!
(WHISPER) There’s nothing here, is there?
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 72
(WHISPER) No. Sometimes an alien ruin is just an alien ruin!
(SUSPICIOUS) What are you saying?
We were wondering if you would care to, ah, read out this inscription of yours?
Isn’t it obvious?
Not to me, no.
It’s our names. Engraved into the stone. Valis, Cardell and Bragg...
(WHISPER) They’re not names, they’re just patterns! Symbols!
(WHISPER) Yes. I’m afraid that confirms your diagnosis. Mr Bragg is quite, quite mad!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 73
44. LABORATORY
You’ve had your memories restored?
Yes. I know... I know who I am now. You understand what you must do?
Now that I’ve isolated the antigen sequence, it should be fairly straightforward to modify the virus to become more transmissible. But there's one thing —
Yes?
I’1l need to test it on the others. The augmented virus could have unpredictable effects, its incubation period may differ.
Very well. I’1ll bring them to you. You can start on the girl.
FX: CARDELL LEAVES. BUTTONS PRESSED. DOOR OPENS, CLOSES
Okay, now Cardell’s gone. Tell me. How did you know about adapting the Cractid antigen?
That’s why you asked for me?
You clearly know far more than you’re letting on. We’ve been working on this for months, only for you to walk in and come up with the answer in a couple of minutes!
It’s because... I’ve been working on Richter’s syndrome too. And I’ve seen the consequences of your re-engineered virus being released!
So what your friends said is true? You really are from the future?
It’s a long story. But the reason we’re here is to try to make sure that that future doesn’t happen!
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 74
45. MEDICAL BAY
FX: DOOR OPENS
Doctor, Tegan! Did you find out anything?
Oh, one or two things.
Bragg, you have to let us help you —
Enforcement Officer Bragg to proceed to facility control room.
FX: DOOR OPENS
Director Cardell, what are you — (doing here)
You just run along to Edgar, Mr Bragg. I’ve come to collect the others. For experimentation.
46. LABORATORY
FX: VALIS WORKING ON EXPERIMENT — MACHINES BEEPING
Bio-technician Valis to proceed to facility control room.
Not now, Edgar.
Priority one.
I’1l be down as soon as I can. Now stop bothering me.
You’re not going?
No. You see, we’re completed our mission. Which means we get our memories back.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 75
Isn’t that good news? Finding out who you really are?
What if I don’t like the person I really am? I mean, I must’ve agreed to come here, to do this. Maybe I don’t want to be that person.
But what about your memories of your family?
Maybe I’m better off not knowing? Being a blank slate. I know enough to know that everything I thought I knew is a lie.
A lie?
I thought I was here to save lives. There, that’s done it.
FX: EXPERIMENT COMPLETED.
You've re-engineered the virus?
I said it would be straightforward.
You can’t intend to go along with this?
I told you. Not my decision. (BEAT) And may Freya forgive me.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 76
47. CONTROL ROOM
FX: DOOR OPENS
Okay, Edgar, what is it?
As the mission goal has been achieved, you may now access your memory lattice.
No. No. I don’t want to [have my —]
In event of resistance, I have the authority to over-rule your decision.
Whose authority?
Yours. Restoring.
FX: EDGAR RESTORING MEMORIES. JUNGLE SOUNDS, ENGINES, SHOUTS
No, it’s a lie. There’s nothing, there is no past! (GASPS)
There is a message included in your memory lattice. Message Signatory: Enforcement Officer Bragg.
Go ahead.
FX: MESSAGE PLAYS. IT’S BRAGG, VOICE SLIGHTLY DISTORTED
(RECORDING)

You're hearing this because the mission has been successful, and you’ve had your memories returned. Now listen carefully. You are an agent working for the Independent Bio-Development Group. We need you to acquire for us a sample of the re- engineered virus and the antiviral solution. And whatever you do, they must not remain in the hands of the Company!
FX: MESSAGE ENDS
(AMUSED) So it seems we did have a traitor in our midst. Me! (BEAT) Edgar, reconfigure access privileges. From now on you will obey only my instructions.
Command accepted.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 77
48. LABORATORY
FX: DOOR OPEN
Inside, all of you.
(SEEING THEM, DELIGHT) Doctor, Tegan — !
Nyssa, you haven’t been harmed?
No, I'm fine —
Bio-Technician Valis, any progress?
I’ve created an augmented viral strain. The sample contained in this phial is enough wipe out a planet.
And the antiviral solution?
Prepared. In the second phial.
You have commenced testing on the woman?
No. And I’m not going to.
Those are the direct instructions of the Company!
I refuse to be complicit in economic mass-murder!
Funny way to commit suicide, but it’s your choice. I’1l just have to perform the experiment myself. You can be first.
No!
FX: DOOR OPENS
Oh no, I wouldn’t do that, if I were you, Director.
COBWEBS by Jonathan Morris Page 78
FX: GUN CLICKS ON
Bragg, what are you doing? Put that gun down at once. That’s an order!
I think you’ll find I’m the one giving the orders. Now. Give me the virus sample.
(WHISPER) Doctor, Tegan — quick, behind the dissection table.
(WHISPER) Why?
(WHISPER) I’ve seen this all before!
